title: 108_s1451
content:
The Act is titled the "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act." It includes amendments to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically amending Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress recognizes that homeless youth face serious health and safety risks due to lack of resources, leading to law enforcement issues in communities. Many young people urgently need temporary shelter. The Federal Government must develop a national reporting system to address the urgent need for temporary shelter and services for homeless youth, including linguistically appropriate care and preventive measures. Improved coordination and collaboration between Federal programs serving runaway and homeless youth is essential for developing a long-term strategy to help these youth successfully transition to adulthood. This includes providing opportunities for education, job skills training, and employment outside of the welfare and law enforcement systems. Federal programs for runaway and homeless youth are crucial for a long-term strategy to address their needs. The heading for part A of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to "Basic Center". Grants for services provided under the Act are also addressed. SEC. 103 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. SEC. 104 repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments. SEC. 104 repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments in the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 105 amends eligibility provisions by replacing "juveniles" with "youth." SEC. 106 recognizes state laws regarding capacity limitations on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 106 recognizes state laws regarding capacity limitations on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 107 addresses maternity group homes. SEC. 107 addresses maternity group homes, amending the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to include parenting skills and define maternity group homes as transitional living arrangements for pregnant or parenting youth. The term 'maternity group home' is defined as a transitional living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic independence for the well-being of their children. SEC. 108 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to allow youth under 18 in a program to stay until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the 540-day period. SEC. 109 addresses coordination assurances for Part A plans. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 addresses coordination agreements for Part B plans. Section 322(a) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include coordination of services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons to ensure that runaway and homeless youth receive information about educational services. The McKinney-Vento Homeless Assistance Act ensures that runaway and homeless youth are informed about educational services available to them under subtitle B of title VII of the Act. SEC. 111 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act amends Section 322(a)(7) to require the development of a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services including education, vocational training, welfare, legal services, and health care. SEC. 112 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act amends Section 341 to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth by consulting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment to demonstration projects. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision related to a study. SEC. 116 sets an age limit for homeless youth. SEC. 116 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act sets an age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter in a center under part A, not more than 18 years of age. Section 388 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to allocate $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and adjust funding for fiscal years 2005-2008. Section 388(a)(2)(B) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to increase the allocation to 45 percent, with a possibility of up to 55 percent in certain fiscal years based on grant obligations and applicant quality. The Secretary of Health and Human Services, in consultation with the United States Interagency Council on Homelessness, must submit a report to Congress on promising strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years of the Act's enactment. Additionally, a study on housing services and strategies is required. SEC. 119. STUDY OF HOUSING SERVICES AND STRATEGIES.

The Secretary of Health and Human Services will conduct a study on housing programs for youth exiting the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, focusing on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and prevention of future homelessness. SEC. 120. RESTRICTION ON USE OF FUNDS. Amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to prohibit the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Requires separate accounting for funds used in such programs. AMENDMENT TO MISSING CHILDREN'S ASSISTANCE ACT: Section 402 of the Act is amended to update the findings related to missing children. The Congress recognizes the grave danger faced by abducted children, who are at risk of physical harm and sexual exploitation. Parents and law enforcement often lack resources for extensive search efforts as abducted children are frequently moved to different locations. The expanded search efforts for abducted children require cooperation and coordination among local, State, and Federal law enforcement agencies. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a national resource center and works in partnership with various government agencies to find missing children. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various government agencies, including the Department of the Treasury and the Department of State, to locate missing children and prevent child victimization. They operate a national and global network connecting with missing children clearinghouses in all 50 states, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, Scotland Yard, the Royal Canadian Mounted Police, INTERPOL headquarters in Lyon, France, and others. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various government agencies and international organizations to transmit images and information about missing children to law enforcement worldwide instantly. SEC. 202. Authorization of appropriations amended to change the year from 2005 to 2008 for grants to the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children. This is part of the Missing Children's Assistance Act. AN ACT to reauthorize programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and the Missing Children's Assistance Act, and for other purposes.
